intro: Hi there, I'm Andrew. I challenge the assumption that you can only be good at one thing, approach something from one point of view, or be one kind of person. Here is a selection of creative and technical projects, both professional and personal, that I've worked on over the years.

projects.description: Of the thousands of rÃ©sumÃ©s that have passed across my desk, the ones that stood out showed the candidate's creativity using color and formatting to tell a story. My rÃ©sumÃ© uses venn diagrams to show, rather than tell, that I'm a multi-disciplinary person. It has a timeline inspired by the Facebook feed to illustrate the journey of my career.
projects.name: RÃ©sumÃ©

projects.description:
At Stanford I majored in Symbolic Systems, an interdisciplinary program that brings together computer science, philosophy, linguistics and psychology. People from diverse backgrounds come together to study the overlaps between these fields, and my concentration was in human computer interaction. One lasting effect was my approach to asking similar questions when comparing the diversity of computer languages and human languages.

Throughout my career, my most successful projects have been grounded in the type of systemic thinking that I learned in this program. I always try to ask questions like: What are we building? What is its reason for being? What is its nature? What are its principles? If you get these things right at the beginning of a project, it sets you up for success down the road.
projects.name: Symbolic Systems

projects.description: I use my website to document my life experiences. I like to make lists of all the places I've been, and the places I want to go. These are grouped into categories like cities, countries, geography, nature, buildings, infrastructure and trains. Looking back and looking forward, I feel like things are in balance when those lists are about the same length. My website is a manifesto on simplicity, and consists of just HTML and emoji, with almost no images or scripts.
projects.name: Website

projects.description: A lot of travel pages on my website have flag emoji that indicate where the things I've visted (or want to visit) are. I wrote a program in Swift to read the HTML pages on my website, count the number of flags of each country on each page, and show the totals in an HTML table. About 90% of the program was written using ChatGPT prompts, saving me time and letting me focus on the parts of the program where I was adding the most value.
projects.name: Flags

projects.description: Wouldn't it be great to have a summary of all the things I've visited in each country? Building upon the Flags project, I wrote a program to parse all the pages on my website and create HTML pages with everything in each country.
projects.name: Countries

projects.description: I've tried to port my interview question solutions to thirteen programming languages. Even while maintaining a reasonable degree of fluency in all of them, it can be hard to remember the subtle differences, so I made a giant cheat sheet of things I do most often in all the languages. I even built a mileage chart style graph that shows the precent similarity between different languages, giving me some fascinating insights into how they're related.
projects.name: Computer Languages

projects.description: I speak English, Russian, French and Dutch. Sometimes for fun when I'm listening to pop music, I like to translate the song into Dutch in my head in realtime to see if I can keep up. I made a web page that translated the titles of some of my favorite songs to Dutch, and a total of nine languages while I was at it. I used the same algorithm for comparing computer lanugages to make a milage chart of human languages, empirically demonstrating the similarity of Germanic, Romance and Slavic languages.
projects.name: Human Languages

projects.description: A JavaScript module for apps running on the Senza platform that collects session statistics and viewing activity and sends it to all Google Analytics. Once you plug it in and turn it on, the rest is completely automatic and requires no changes to the app. It takes advantage of a special feature of the Senza cloud browser that allows it to reliably send an end-of-session summary after the client disconnects. The analytics platform doesn't need to interpret lots of low-level events: just a nice clean summary of how much time the app spent in each lifecycle state and what the viewer watched. 100% vibe coded and production ready!
projects.name: Analytics
projects.summary: Sends lifecycle and playback stats to Google Analytics

projects.name: Aquarium
projects.summary: Screensaver that shows how to use emoji

projects.description: The Banner app is the canonical reference implementation for playing video on Senza â€” the app every developer looks at first to understand how foreground and background modes work together. It's deliberately, almost stubbornly simple: load a video, show a banner on top, press OK to hand off seamlessly to the background player, press any key to come back. The Senza ShakaPlayer handles the sync between the browser player and the remote player automatically, and the auto-background feature makes the whole thing production-ready with a single configuration call. The pro version adds URL configuration for DRM, audio tracks, subtitles, and more. Keeping this app simple was a feature, not a limitation â€” and after watching Big Buck Bunny with a burned-in timecode approximately one million times, the seamless frame-accurate handoff between foreground and background never gets old.
projects.name: Banner Pro
projects.summary: More configurable version of bannner

projects.name: Bistro
projects.summary: Menu signage use case for Marriott

projects.description: A digital signage experience that showcases one of the most elegant features of the Senza platform: the ability to seamlessly hand off between a rich HTML foreground and full-quality streaming video. The app displays a single evocative word â€” smooth, delicious, dark â€” in a custom font with dissolve animations and randomized chocolate-palette colors, then hands off to a streaming video of tempting chocolate before cycling back again. Drop in the analytics module and it captures the whole story with a single function call: which videos played, which words appeared, and how the foreground/background ratio stabilized at exactly the 23% you'd predict from the scripted timing.
projects.name: Chocolate
projects.summary: Digital signage that alternates between HTML and video streams

projects.name: Comics
projects.summary: Creates comic books in any style from video frames

projects.description: Dunnet is a classic 1980s text adventure game that shipped with macOS as part of the Emacs distribution all the way through version 10.14 â€” yes, really. This port is equal parts ridiculous and delightful: a six-button TV remote turns out to be a surprisingly natural way to play. Arrow keys handle movement in all four directions, and the Back button drops into a command menu where you can navigate through every available verb and noun combination â€” the same Escape key that triggers command mode in Emacs. The implementation is a genuine example of how to make an existing web app fully navigable with a remote control, wrapped in the excuse of doing something completely absurd. You can pick up the shovel, eat the shovel, or do basically anything with the shovel. Just know that some commands end the game faster than others.
projects.name: Dunnet
projects.summary: Use arrows to play a command line adventure game

projects.description: A deceptively simple app that solves a real platform problem: because Senza apps run in a cloud browser, a geolocation service would normally place every user in a data center. The Flags app demonstrates how the Senza SDK exposes the physical device's real IP and country code â€” the entire app is essentially one line to get the country code and one line to display the flag. Developers can spoof the country in the simulator to test how their app behaves anywhere in the world. The video tutorial makes this concrete in the most memorable way possible: it opens with a ridiculous fake British accent, and when the VPN disconnects mid-recording and the country flips back to the US, so does the voice.
projects.name: Flags
projects.summary: Shows flag of current country using geolocation

projects.description: A digital signage example that shows what flight departure boards could look like if they ran on a powerful platform like Senza. The app alternates between departure information in multiple languages and stunning wallpaper of featured destinations. The data is fake but the pipeline is real, with the frontend loading airports, airlines and flights over clean APIs from a node backend. Languages change with subtle animations, text is rendered with high-quality fonts, and the interface is flipped for right-aligned languages. The app is optimized for the Senza platform, and runs in a loop with one second of GPU-powered animations followed by seven seconds of efficient static content. You wish airport signage looked this good!
projects.name: Flights
projects.summary: Flight arrivals board for an aiport

projects.description: A video wall built with surprisingly little code, named after a trade show demo from a previous life â€” a wink to anyone who was there. The trick is pure CSS: send a 4K video to all four Senza screens, make each one overflow-crop its assigned quadrant with a negative margin offset, and let a tiny Socket.IO server keep the timecodes in sync. Play, pause, skip â€” it all works seamlessly across the wall. The elegant part is what it isn't: a colleague's attempt to do the same thing by hacking deep into the Senza platform took roughly 100 times the code. Sometimes the best engineering is knowing which layer to work at.
projects.name: Video Wall
projects.summary: Play a video across four screens

projects.description: A real problem, solved in real time: at a Senza hackathon, every device in a tenant loads the same URL â€” so how do you support a room full of developers each hacking on their own device simultaneously? The Gateway app is a vibe-coded redirect service that uses the Senza SDK to read each device's ID the moment it connects, looks it up in a shared mapping, and bounces it to whatever URL that developer has registered. A clean admin UI lets anyone on the team point their device at their local environment without touching config files or the Remote Debugger. There's even a one-command ngrok integration that restarts your tunnel and updates your device's entry in the gateway automatically. It saved the day at the hackathon, and it's been running in production ever since.
projects.name: Gateway
projects.summary: Configure devices in a tenant to load different web apps

projects.description: Ever wish you could just talk to your TV and it would show you whatever you want? With the Imagine app, the user scans a QR code, speaks a prompt, and seconds later an image of whatever they imagined appears on the screen. But what if they want something more engaging? Pivot! I upgraded the app so that instead of generating an image, it can spin up an entire app experience from a spoken request. A minute later, they can be using itâ€”optimized for display on TV with remote control input. Welcome to the world of software on demand that is written for the user right when they need it.
projects.name: Imagine
projects.summary: Speak a prompt to generate an image or app using AI

projects.description: Think of it as a TV version of those mailers with phone numbers for local services. It geolocates the user, searches Google Places for the nearest hospital, pharmacy, dentist, etc. and displays them in a navigable grid with address and phone number. Select any tile and it drops a pin on a full-screen map. Small but important detail: the emergency number automatically displays as 999, 911 or 112 depending on the country. Nothing earth-shattering, but a practical demonstration of how a TV app can be composed from a handful of simple functions snapped together.
projects.name: Local Services
projects.summary: Show local services like doctors near you

projects.description: A real-time Washington Metro arrivals app built for a pitch at the DC-area headquarters of a major hospitality company. The app is totally simple: a three-screen navigation flow (pick a line, pick a station, see live arrivals) powered by the WMATA API, with a metro station wallpaper and typography that looks like it belongs in the system. The whole thing is driven by a reusable typeahead.js script â€” drop it into any page with links and it instantly becomes remote-control navigable. "Did you use AI?" they asked. "No, it was so simple I didn't have to!" My colleagues did the heavy lifting that day, but showing up with something polished, working, and fun helped set the tone for the whole conversation.
projects.name: Train Arrivals
projects.summary: Live metro arrivals for Washington Metro

projects.description: During a pitch to a major mobile operator, someone asked: "Could you build a lifestyle app where you snap photos on your phone while traveling and they show up as a screensaver on your parents' TV?" Yup, I can vibe code that. The Photo Stream app does exactly this: the TV generates a persistent QR code, family members scan it on their phones, tap to upload a photo, and it appears on screen within seconds. The implementation is clean end-to-end â€” the phone gets a pre-signed S3 URL from the server and uploads directly, bypassing the server entirely for the image bytes, then pings via Socket.IO to notify the TV in real time. Photos persist across sessions so the stream just keeps growing. The customer was delighted, and the use case basically sold itself.
projects.name: Photo Stream
projects.summary: Upload pictures from a phone to view on TV

projects.description: A demonstration of contextual video overlays built on top of Big Buck Bunny â€” because at this point the bunny deserves a revenue stream. Cheeky ads appear at specific timecodes tied to moments in the video: a bird on screen triggers a "find out what people are tweeting!" popup, the bunny gets an XL rabbit ad, and so on. The real Senza trick is the AlarmManager: video plays in background mode most of the time, but a platform alarm wakes the app and fires the popup right on cue â€” something setTimeout can't do when the app is suspended.
projects.name: Popup Ads
projects.summary: Display popups at specific timecodes in a video

projects.description: What if you could watch a car commercial, press a button, and instantly see where to buy that car near you? That's the Product Finderâ€”a TV app that grabs a still frame from whatever video is playing, uses ChatGPT to identify the product, looks up nearby retailers with the Google Places API, and drops a pin on a Google Map, all in a few seconds. Each piece is a simple function; the magic is in the pipeline. It's also a great example of a real-world vibe coding session: start with a rough idea, compose a handful of API calls together, and iterating until the result feels cinematicâ€”a smooth animated overlay that grows from a thumbnail preview into a full map without interrupting the video underneath.
projects.name: Product Finder
projects.summary: Identifies products in a video and shows a map where to buy them

projects.description: A playful proof of concept for AI-powered digital signage: what if every store location could show a locally relevant lifestyle image featuring your product, generated fresh each time? The app builds a simple prompt â€” a person with a product, in an artistic style, on the street in the device's geolocated city â€” and hands it to DALL-E. The whole thing is about 50 lines of code, and the results are surprisingly cinematic. No two runs are the same, which is either a feature or a bug depending on your brand guidelines.
projects.name: Product Placement
projects.summary: Generates product images with configurable styles in current location

projects.description: A demo that shows what's possible when you pair a smartphone with a Senza TV app. Scan a QR code on the TV and your phone instantly becomes a smart remote with four input modes: tappable buttons that work just like the physical remote, a trackpad that translates finger gestures into smooth on-screen movement, a keyboard that forwards every keystroke in real time, and a microphone that listens for voice commands and maps them to actions. Under the hood it's elegantly simpleâ€”a 15-line Socket.IO server that reflects events between the phone and TV. The TV and physical remote share the same event handler, so the smart remote is a drop-in addition to any existing app.
projects.name: Remote
projects.summary: Smart remote with buttons, trackpad, keyboard and voice input

projects.description: A four-screen synchronized digital signage demo for restaurants, with a mouth-watering lineup of food photography that will make you seriously question your lunch plans. A Node.js server with Socket.IO keeps all screens in lockstep, advancing slides on a shared timer and broadcasting state to every display simultaneously. Images can cascade across all four screens like a carousel, advance one screen at a time, or jump randomly â€” all configurable from an on-screen settings panel that lets you dial in slide order, transition style (fade, slide, slide-over), and speed without touching the code.
projects.name: Signs
projects.summary: Digital signage with images carousel that slides between screens

projects.name: Stopwatch
projects.summary: Displays time spent in foreground, background and suspended

projects.name: Subway Status
projects.summary: Digital signage with fake alerts from New York City Subway

projects.description: A major TV operator's pitch requirement was refreshingly honest: our customers don't like change, so can you make something that looks like our old thing? Eye roll. "Make a TV guide grid from the 1990s" â€” and this is what came back. The font, the blue grid, the sticky channel column, the 60-minute show spanning two cells â€” all of it, conjured from a single prompt. It even picked the program names, pretty much capturing the vibe of TV in the 1990s.
projects.name: TV Guide
projects.summary: Vibe coded TV guide from the 90s

projects.name: Vertical
projects.summary: Shows how to use CSS to rotate the screen for digital signage

projects.name: Video Tutorials
projects.summary: Watch the Senza video tutorials on Senza, how meta

projects.name: Watch Party
projects.summary: Fork of program guide that keeps multiple instances synced

projects.description: Some streaming apps that replace broadcast TV are required to support emergency alerts â€” and Senza has a group messaging API just for this. Compose an alert in the handy dashboard, pick a disaster icon (tsunami, wildfire, zombie apocalypse), select some groups to target, and broadcast it to all devices in those groups simultaneously. The TV app wakes up if it's in background mode and displays the alert. The demo keeps the disaster selection appropriately lighthearted given the timesâ€”but the infrastructure is real, and Senza customers will be well prepared for the next asteroid impact.
projects.name: Zombies
projects.summary: Warn viewers of zombie apocalypse using Alarm Manager

projects.description: A picture-in-picture demo that showcases two simultaneous video decodes in the cloud browser. Two streams play at onceâ€”one fullscreen, one tucked in the cornerâ€”and pressing a button swaps them with a smooth CSS animation. What makes it feel magical is the audio cross-fade: as one video shrinks, its volume fades out; as the other expands, it fades in. The result feels less like a UI transition and more like a mixing board. Demonstrates that Senza's cloud browser is genuinely powerful enough to handle multi-video experiences that would be unthinkable on a traditional set-top box.
projects.name: Zoom
projects.summary: Switch two videos between PIP and full screen (needs RTP audio)

projects.name: Senza Developer Context
projects.summary: Senza developer documentation in AI readable markdown format

projects.name: Senza Agent
projects.summary: MCP tool for accessing the developer docs using AI

projects.name: Senza Devices MCP Server
projects.summary: MCP tool for connecting to the Senza Devices API

projects.name: Bigquery MCP Server
projects.summary: MCP tool for getting stats from Google Analytics via BigQuery

projects.description: I started KavaSoft in 2002, with the dream of writing applications for the brand new Mac OS X operating system. I started by porting one of my favorite games from the original Macintosh, which became iConquer. Over the next nine years I released a suite of apps for organizing your photos by content, sharing your favorite music, downloaded images from websites, sorting your movie collection, translating text in apps and much more. This was a decade before the app store, so I had to work out distribution, payments and software updates in order to make KavaSoft into a profitable enterprise.
projects.name: KavaSoft

projects.description: The original game of world conquest for Mac OS X! iConquer is based on a version of Risk that was one of my favorite games for the original Macintosh. It features stunning high-resolution maps based on satellite photography, and a variety of computer player personalities based on artificial intelligence algorithms. A community of developers contributed maps, player algorithms and language translations.
projects.name: iConquer

projects.description: Making iConquer maps was a graphic design project of its own. Whether mapping countries in the world or neighborhoods in a city, I started by compositing satellite imagery at what was at the time insanely high resolution (using 4K about a decade before it was cool). I created an Xcode plugin that allowed third-party developers to contribute maps to the iConquer ecosystem, and was surprised by their creativity: everything from the solar system to a “boss mode” that let you keep playing on an Excel spreadsheet.
projects.name: iConquer Maps

projects.description: Shoebox lets you organize your photos by content, and find the photo you want instantly. It's like a knowledge base for your photo library, with hierarchical categories that let you define the times, people, places and things that define your world. For example, if you tagged a photo of the Eiffel Tower, you could find it when searching for Paris or France. You could import photos from your camera, back up to DVD, and even create searchable websites.
projects.name: Shoebox

projects.description: KavaTunes creates interactive websites that look and work just like iTunes on your computer. Visitors can browse through your music and playlists, and even play music by streaming it from your computer. The home page and artist pages feature personalized top ten lists like most played albums and songs. You can even browse music just as if you were holding an iPod! KavaTunes can also search the internet to add cover artwork to your music.
projects.name: KavaTunes

projects.description: KavaMovies lets you organize the movies you've seen, the movies you want to see, and the movies in your collection. It connects to IMDB and downloads tons of information about each of your movies in realtime. Movies are linked together by actor, director, genre, keyword, and more; making it easy to surf through all the movies you care about.
projects.name: KavaMovies

projects.description: There are millions of images on the web, but how do you find and download them without clicking on them one at a time? HyperImage is an industrial-strength tool for searching the web and downloading entire websites worth of pictures. Just enter an address or keyword, and watch as thousands of pictures stream down to your computer. HyperImage knows about the structure of popular websites, can easily download entire blogs, and is also a full-featured Tumblr client.
projects.name: HyperImage

projects.description: KavaServices can add commands to the Services menu that let you translate text, search websites, encode special characters, calculate mathematical expressions, process text in numerous ways, and even run terminal commands! These commands replace the selected text in any Mac application, just like magic. You don't need to switch to a different program, or even copy and paste.
projects.name: KavaServices

projects.description: It's hard to believe now, but there was no App Store in 2002. When I started KavaSoft, I had to build out the entire infrastructure for the KavaSoft Store to help customers discover, download, purchase and update their apps. The system integrated with APIs from payment processors like PayPal and Kagi. I even wrote a Mac license manager app for monitoring sales and assisting with customer service.
projects.name: KavaSoft Store

projects.description: NDS was the world leader in television set-top box middleware, the operating systems that run on cable and satellite boxes. As part of the New Initiatives team, I helped develop proof-of-concept systems to maintain thought leadership in the television space. When NDS was acquired by Cisco, I engaged with the developer community to build excitement about advanced technologies in telepresence, indoor navigation and smart cities.
projects.name: NDS / Cisco

projects.description:
The world of cable and satellite set-top boxes is completely separate from the world of consumer devices. What if we could build a platform to let developers write apps to a single standard that would make them compatible with television platforms around the world? The NDS Service Delivery Platform offers APIs to get schedule information, see what's playing, act as a remote control, schedule recordings and play back recorded content.

I was responsible for developing an ecosystem of client apps to demonstrate the potential of the platform. I worked with marketing to engage with both television providers and app developers to sell the dream and turn it into reality.
projects.name: Service Delivery Platform

projects.description: The film Home by Yann Arthus-Bertrand features stunning aerial photography from around the world. This second screen app for iPad shows satellite maps of the locations featured in the movie, zooming from one location to another as scenes change. The location menu lets you jump between scenes, for a non-linear viewing experience that transforms the way in which you consume content.
projects.name: Home

projects.description: If all your friends like a TV show, you probably will enjoy it too. Combining the power of the SDP and Facebook APIs, Social Zapper reinvents the traditional schedule grid by showing which of your friends like each show that's on right now, even allowing you to reorder the channels based on the popularity. It can also recommend shows that you might want to binge based on the overall popularity in your social network. This prototype was later incorporated as a feature of Bento, our cloud-based STB interface.
projects.name: Social Zapper

projects.description: This app demonstrated the potential of SDP for rich syncrhonization of time-based metadata between a set-top box and an iPad second screen. As you watched the “star in a reasonably-priced car” segment in an episode of Top Gear on your TV, you could use your iPad to follow their progress around the race track. Playback state was syncrhonized in both directions, so you could hit fast forward on your remote control or in the app to make the car go faster… or even drag the red dot along the track to scrub back and forth on the TV. The seamless link between the screens was magical.
projects.name: Top Gear

projects.description: Imagine if video screens could be as large as you wanted, the size of an entire wall or table? Surfaces was a project that explored the possibilities of creating scalable displays, pushing the relevant content to a number of tiled screens. I created clients that would allow widgets to span adjacent iPads. You could literally drag a widget from one iPad to another, even if one was running a browser and the other a native client written in Swift.
projects.name: Surfaces

projects.description: Flare is a concept ecosystem that combines indoor location technologies, wearable devices and an object-oriented data model to help people explore interior spaces and interact with objects in their environment. I implemented the backend in Node, the API layer, and frameworks and demo applications for web, Mac, iOS, Apple Watch, Android, Android Watch and Python. I released an SDK and developer documentation on Ciso's DevNet developer portal, and hosted hackathons in which external developers used the SDK to develop projects. I presented the platform at the National Retail Federation trade show in New York, giving demos to the engineering leadership of a hundred major retail companies.
projects.name: Flare

projects.description: I did a hacakthon project in which I replaced the entire SDP context and control architecture with one based on the Twitter platform. Your set-top box had its own account and would tweet what you were watching, along with the title card and a description of the episode. Then you could DM your STB with messages like “watch @topgear”, and it would find that show in the grid and change channels for you. Got it up and running in four hours.
projects.name: Twitter TV

projects.description: When watching an Apple keynote, there are parts that are more exciting than others. I tried making a highlight reel of the iPad 3 launch, which took hours of my time. What if we could do this automatically by measuring the volume of tweets on a particular hashtag like #ipad during an event? I wrote an algorithm to do exactly that, and made an auto-generated highlight reel. The money shot? When they announced the pricing. Turns out the reel based on hashtag buzz was pretty much the same as the manually curated one. Proved a point in about half a day of work.
projects.name: Social Highlights

projects.description: I gave a presentation on privacy considerations in the context of building a personalized television platform. In a world where many people want to share everything about what they're doing, would we consider your television viewing history to be sensitive personally identifiable information? Everyone knows that the Queen watches television, but can you imagine if the shows she watched turned up in the tabloids? The talk covered the important points of what privacy is, why it's important, how to protect it, and specific learnings applicable to our current projects.
projects.name: Privacy

projects.description: I designed a poster for the 2013 NDS developer conference in Bangkok on the theme of “the power of an object oriented system lies not in the objects themselves, but in the connections between them.”
projects.name: Connections

projects.description: Compass is the #1 real estate brokerage in the United States, and also a tech company that creates software to make its real estate agents successful. I joined when engineering had 60 people and over five years watched it go through a period of hypergrowth to 1200 engineers. It was also my chance to move into engineering management and build several awesome, high-performing teams.
projects.name: Compass

projects.description: Beautiful marketing materials are a core part of the Compass brand image, but with the massive growth of the brokerage it became untenable for designers to make them by hand. My team and I worked with marketing to essentially distill the brain of a designer into an app called Marketing Center, so agents could make high-quality materials using a self-service tool. It gave them enough flexibility to differentiate themselves while at the same time keeping everything on-brand.
projects.name: Marketing Center

projects.description: Marketing Center lets Compass agents create a variety of kinds of print marketing materials, including the listing cards that are displayed in office windows. I worked with the marketing team to create these layouts and implemented them as templates in Marketing Center. So when you walk by a Compass office and see listings in the window, I made that happen.
projects.name: Window Displays

projects.description: When you're developing software, you tend to run a program over and over in test mode. But the experience is totally different when you're using it for real. One day I used Marketing Center to make a brochure for my own farmhouse in the south of France, and had it professionally printed. I put a lot of love into that brochure, which gave me an entirely new perspective on the software product that my team had created.
projects.name: Farm Brochure

projects.description: The Compass Marketing Center app made it easy for agents to make any kind of marketing materials, assuming they knew what they wanted to make. But it was still a challenge to remember what materials for what listings they needed to make when, and to decide which collateral types and templates would be most effective. I led the Marketing Automation team in building a system to coordinate an agent's overall marketing strategy, using AI to give every agent the experience of having a dedicated marketing coach.
projects.name: Marketing Automation

projects.description: As Compass scaled organically, agent information was spread across twenty different systems. The first team that I managed built a user adminstration tool called Agent at a Glance (A3G), which let our agent support team get the full picture without having to sign in to multiple systems. We took full advantage of a microservices-based architecture, with each service storing or retrieving a single type of data.
projects.name: Agent at a Glance

projects.description: Identifying the same people in different databases can be a tricky problem. In an ideal world, people would all have a unique identifier that we could use to join records across databases. However, when this is not available, it may be necessary to try to use people's names for matching. As it turns out, people's names can be messy, and are less suitable for use as unique identifiers than you might hope. I wrote a blog post about fuzzy name matching, and you can look at the source code.
projects.name: Fuzzy Name Matching

projects.description: Marketing Center lets users design print-ready marketing materials such as flyers, brochures, postcards and notecards. It outputs web content, which needs to be converted to a PDF that it can be sent to a print fulfillment vendor. I wrote a blog post about writing a Go service to convert web pages to PDF using headless Chrome.
projects.name: HTML to PDF Conversion

projects.description: When I was at Compass I developed a set of coding interview questions that candidates were unlikely to have encountered before. I tried to make questiosn that were fun and interesting, and related to the real world in some meaningful way. I also wrote up solutions to the questions in thirteen different programming languages, to try to force myself to approach each problem from many different different perspectives.
projects.name: Interview Questions

projects.description: When I was young a friend presented me with the four fours problem: using just the number four exactly four times, can you write a mathematical expression that evaluates to every number from 1 to 100? I wrote an interactive explorer in React that helps candidates visualize the question. It's an exercise in finding the simplicity in what seems like a complex problem, working forwards from what you do know instead of trying to work backwards from what you want to find out. See the solutions in several languages, including an elegant one-liner in Clojure.
projects.name: ðŸ”¢ Four Fours

projects.description: This problem asks you to write a program to calculate the time that it would take to commute to the Compass office using the New York City Subway. You can walk to a station, take a train to another station, and from there walk to the office. As an extension, you can add the ability to transfer between trains. I made an interactive subway map that helps people visualize the algorithm. It's a fun interview question because it gets candidates thinking about coming to Compass!
projects.name: 🧭 Subway Directions

projects.description: Here's a fun party trick. Go to any English language Wikipedia page, and click on the first link in the body of the article. Keep doing that, and you'll go from concrete to increasingly abstract subjects, most likely eventually arriving at the articles on Existence or Awareness. Given a list of recently featured articles and the artciles they link to, the task is to construct an outline. The challenge is that there are no root nodes, as you typically get into a loop of articles that link to each other. I've heard candidates remark, “wow, you've changed the way I think about existence and awareness!”
projects.name: â›“ï¸ Wiki Links

projects.description: Pontifex is an encryption algorithm featured in the book Cryptonomicon by Neal Stephenson. It allows two people to exchange encrypted messages, as long as each of them has a deck of cards. Encrypting and decrypting the message uses a process called shuffling as described in the algorithm. In porting my solution to different languages I wound up writing some JavaScript that looked remarkably like Clojure, the closest I've seen to “having an accent” in a programming language.
projects.name: ðŸƒ Pontifex

projects.description: Train schedules contain a lot of data and can be hard to read. In 1885, EJ Marey invented the graphical train schedule, which represents the entire schedule as a graph of the position over time of each train on the line. For this project I made an animated graph of the New York Subway's 7 Train, including a display of the train arrival countdown board. You can even simulate the effect of delays, try setting it to “total chaos”.
projects.name: ðŸš‰ Subway Countdown

projects.description: At Compass I noticed that some people had first names that were the same as other people's last names. I made a directed graph that showed how everyone's names were connected, and kept it up to date as the company grew over the years. I made a magic names interview question that asked candidates to build a graph structure, count the number of clusters of each size, and find how many people were in the “big cloud”. Seeing how the results changed if they added themself to the graph gave candidates a sense of belonging!
projects.name: Magic Names

projects.description: Cryptocurrencies are designed around proof of work algorithms, which essentially prove that a computer burned a certain number of pointless processor cycles. They do this by calculating checksums of a large number of values until they find one that by chance ends with a specific number of zeroes. Hashcash is a protocol that uses a similar approach for avoiding spam: if email senders have to waste even a small amount of processor cycles, it's the digital equivalent of buying a stamp.
projects.name: ðŸ’µ Hashcash

projects.description: Functional Objective-C is a category that adds functional programming methods to Objective-C. Going beyond foreach, filter, map and reduce, it adds around 60 methods and was inspired by the Clojure cheatsheet. I even used it to convert my Four Fours implementation into a one-liner, as inspired by the Clojure version! The whole project is tongue-in-cheek, a work of art that is beautiful and useless at the same time.
projects.name: ðŸ“¦ Functional Objective-C

projects.description: When I was young I was fascinated by the original Macintosh, and knew I would work for Apple one day. I was ironically still considered “the Apple guy” even when I was working at Apple. It was an incredible time to work there, as the results of Steve Jobs' transformation bore fruit: Mac OS X, the iPod, the iTunes Store, and retail stores. Oh yeah, and my email address was andrew@apple.com.
projects.name: Apple

projects.description: I was part of team of three software engineers that developed Apple Sales Web, an app that resellers around the world used to connect with the company. It was implemented in WebObjects, a technology that Apple got from NeXT for creating object oriented web apps connected to relational databases using the same foundation that Mac and iOS apps use today.
projects.name: Apple Sales Web

projects.description: My team adapted Apple Sales Web to support the company's own stores, helping communicate with retail employees and ensure consistency between stores, especially when rolling out design updates and new products. Everyone at Apple is entirely responsible for some small aspect of the business; I wrote the code that got the shopping bags from the warehouses to the stores. Every time I saw someone walking out of a store with their purchase in a bag I felt a little bit proud.
projects.name: Apple Retail Web

projects.description: I developed an internal admin application to help our admin team provide support to our users. One of the great things about building internal tools is that you can observe people using them, and make small improvements that save them a huge amount of time. At Apple even the internal tools are elegant and beautiful, and I made a library of widgets that let our WebObjects apps look just like the recently released Mac OS X operating system and its Aqua interface.
projects.name: User Admin Site

projects.description:
My first job was selling and fixing Macs at a small shop called MacUpgrades. I was particularly good at sales because I was very knowledgable about the products and believed in what I was saying. Back then, memory came in modules that snapped into the logic board, which was easier to do in some models than others. Computers broke all the time and you needed to have them fixed. 
I dyed my hair bondi blue for the launch of the original iMac.
projects.name: MacUpgrades

projects.description: I had a pretty extensive collection of Apple computers and related materials, and donated most of it to the Computer Museum of the University of Amsterdam. So you can go visit their Zamler-Carhart wing of Apple technology. Two of the models I've kept are a Macintosh Plus (1986) and Macintosh SE (1987), which I spray painted red and purple, respectively.
projects.name: Mac Collection

projects.description: In 2002 I gave a presentation at Apple on an early version of iConquer to the Bay Area NeXT Group (BANG). It focused on things I'd learned as a developer writing an application for the relatively new Mac OS X operating system.
projects.name: BANG Presentation

projects.description: KavaFoto was my brand as a photographer. The KavaFoto website was powered by Shoebox, letting visitors browse all my photos by category. The home page has a high degree of randomness, pulling random photos from random categories to suprise you every time.
projects.name: KavaFoto

projects.description: For three years I was the de facto photographer of the composition department at the Royal Conservatoire in the The Hague. I documented over a hundred concerts, using my Shoebox program to organize photos and present them on the KavaFoto website indexed by event, venue, composer, performer and instrument.
projects.name: Concerts

projects.description: I made microsites for some of my composer friends that pulled content dynamically from my own site. Whenever I took a picture of them or one of their compositions, it would automatically add fresh content to their microsites without any additional work on my part.
projects.name: Composers

projects.description: Considering I'm more likely to take pictures of rocks than people, it was ironic that I had a fifteen minute career as a fashion photographer. I shot a fashion show at De Haagse Hogeschool and worked with a number of models in The Hague.
projects.name: Fashion

projects.description: Kick the Can was a protest against the intrusion of commercialism in the Dutch academic music scene. To make the point, two friends and I physically kicked a can 22 kilometers from Rotterdam to The Hague. I designed a poster series to promote the event (patterned on “Yes We Can”), and documented the protest concert. One professor remarked, “we haven't had this kind of spirit around here since the sixties.”
projects.name: Kick the Can

projects.description: Here are some books that I made of my photo portfolio in 2005-2006.
projects.name: Photo Books

projects.description: In 2001 we sent photo albums to all of our family members, each with a card in the format of a National Geographic cover that highlighted the selection of photos. We must have done something right because one of my aunts didn't get the joke and thought it was a legit magazine cover.
projects.name: National Geographic

projects.description: When I was in the French countryside during the first wave of covid, I adapted that hobby to exploring every trail around our house. I recorded every walk with my Apple Watch, imported the route into a program called Iphigénie, overlaid the paths on topographic and satellite maps, and printed posters that I could hang on my wall. I even made walking patterns in the fields, like spirals, fans, zigzags and figure eights. When I lived in Dakar for three months during the second wave, I adapted the same approach to an urban environment, walking the perimter and all the major streets of the city, and making some fun “street art” designs.
projects.name: Hiking Maps

projects.description: The Shake Shack project is designed for teaching students who are new to programming how to build a full-stack web app. It can store the menu in a MongoDB database, load the data in a backend service and serve it up with a REST API, and connect to the API to load a dynamic web page. It's everything you need and nothing you don't!
projects.name: Shake Shack

projects.description: I wrote a Wordle solver in Swift that basically plays the game for you. Each time you guess a word, you enter in the response that indicates which letters are in the right place, wrong place or not in the word. It will then provide a list of the best words for you to play next. From my point of view, I'm not cheating: I just took my own strategy and taught the computer to do it for me.
projects.name: Wordle

projects.description: I significantly improved my Dutch comprehension by reading the book De Ontdekking van de Hemel by Harry Mulisch, considered to be the master work of twentieth century Dutch literature. I wrote a program in Objective-C to process the text of the book, break apart compound and conjugated words, translate them to English, and create a dictionary of Dutch as used in the book. The dictionary is in the form of a tag cloud, with more frequently used words in larger text, and words with common prefixes grouped together.
projects.name: Dutch Dictionary

projects.description: I did a wine and painting team building event one time in which I painted a photo I took of a vintage tram in Lisbon. My phone kept going to sleep and I had paint all over my hands, so I wound up kind of painting it from memory rather than looking at the original while I was working. It turned out a bit abstract, but not bad considering that I was in a rush to finish in 45 minutes. I had the original photo printed on canvas so the two could be displayed side by side.
projects.name: Painting

projects.description: I like to stay in touch with my high school teachers at St. Albans. While I mostly think of myself as a techie, I think that my European history teacher Ted Eagles had the biggest effect on shaping my world view. On a visit in 2010, I wrote Ted a twenty page paper on the Evolution of European Empire Building, constrasting the European Union with the Soviet Union. As one does, just for old times sake.
projects.name: History Paper

projects.description: The author John Irving refers to a number of recurring themes in his novels. I made a table, based on data from Wikipedia, on which themes occur in which books. With his most recent book The Last Chairlift, he's obviously trolling his fans because it contains all the themes.
projects.name: John Irving
